channel.title: Posts on A Hugo website
channel.description: Recent content in Posts on A Hugo website

item.title: 2023 August 15 - Spam Email
item.description: The goal of this work is to apply my understanding of data towards real world projects using R and the tidyverse. The data used here is from the TidyTuesday project. Check Out This Week’s Data # load R packages for analysis library(tidyverse) library(tidytuesdayR) # Download the weekly data and make available in the tt object. # Using the last_tuesday function gives us the latest TidyTuesday data from today's date tues <- last_tuesday("2023-08-15") tt <- tt_load(tues) ## ## Downloading file 1 of 1: `spam.

item.title: Practicing BigQuery, SQL, and R
item.description: Purpose I’ve recently been learning and practicing SQL, and given the fact that Google BigQuery is such a big deal now, I wanted to find a way to implement practice SQL by pulling from BigQuery’s public data sets and then visualizing in R. Luckily, I found this tutorial on YouTube from John Little that acts as a tutorial/walk-through. We will be querying JHU’s Covid19 public dataset for practice. # Install packages if not already installed #install.

item.title: 2023 MAY 23 - Squirrels in Central Park
item.description: The goal of this work is to apply my understanding of data towards real world projects using R and the tidyverse. The data used here is from the TidyTuesday project. Check Out This Week’s Data # load R packages for analysis library(tidyverse) library(tidytuesdayR) # Download the weekly data and make available in the tt object. # Using the last_tuesday function gives us the latest TidyTuesday data from today's date tues <- last_tuesday("2023-5-23") tt <- tt_load(tues) ## ## Downloading file 1 of 1: `squirrel_data.

item.title: TidyModels Screencast - Horror Movie Descriptions
item.description: Purpose This document is an adaptation of the “Use OpenAI text embeddings for horror movie descriptions” by Julia Silge. The goal is to apply my training in R towards real world projects, including the use of OpenAI towards a data science project. The data used here is from the TidyTuesday project. #load r packages library(tidytuesdayR) library(tidymodels) library(httr) Data Exploration #get horror movie data from GitHub using tidytuesdayR package tuesdata <- tt_load("2022-11-01") horror_movies <- tuesdata$horror_movies #create a sample of the horror movie data by filtering movies that are in the English language and remove movies that do not have an overview #use slice sample to randomly select rows set.
